update.description:
## Random world generation

1. Install Ruby:

        sudo apt-get install ruby2.5 ruby2.5-dev

1. Go to the worlds directory

        cd  subt_gazebo/worlds

1. Run erb to generate a random world with default params

        erb tile.world.erb > cave.world
 
1. Try different options, such as `n=3` to generate a 3x3 world:

        erb n=3 tile.world.erb > cave_3x3.world

1. ... or s=100 to set the random seed

        erb s=100 tile.world.erb > cave_s100.world

1. In the future, the same script could be used for mines as long as the meshes follow the same naming scheme

Randomly generated and committed cave world:

![Screenshot from 2018-08-09 17-55-43.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1886489238-Screenshot%20from%202018-08-09%2017-55-43.png)

## Cave world

* I'm not using the `cave_tile_ramp` yet, which will need logic for adding new "storeys"
* I didn't add the game logic plugin or the gates because those seem to be very specific to the lava tube for now

## Launch

* Substituted `lava_tube.launch` with `competition.launch`, which loads the lava tube by default, for example:

        roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch

* Other worlds can be used by setting the `scenario` argument, for example, to use the cave world:

        roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=cave

* Also adapted the `subt_example` launch files to use this. So by default they still do what they used to (`lava_tube`), but you can pass `scenario` to override it, for example:

        roslaunch subt_example jackal.launch scenario:=cave

    ![jackalstart.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1334431747-jackalstart.png)

    or

        roslaunch subt_example iris.launch scenario:=cave

    ![irisstart.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3585875739-irisstart.png)

    or 

        roslaunch subt_example husky.launch scenario:=cave

    ![huskystart.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1809813129-huskystart.png)

## Updates 1b43c62

* Outside staging area
* Using the pre-existing cave entrance as a placeholder for now
* Scaled blockers so they cover the whole exit
* Support rectangular layouts for longer caves
* Outside lighting

![cave_5.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/199001242-cave_5.png)
![cave_6.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3936076220-cave_6.png)
update.title: Randomized cave tiles

content.raw: It was mainly a placeholder, feel free to deprecate as necessary.  This looks to cover what the python script was doing.
content.html: It was mainly a placeholder, feel free to deprecate as necessary. This looks to cover what the python script was doing.

Updated docker: fde84fe

Looking at the tutorials I now saw that the python-based world_generator is quite developed and even has a tutorial already. I had understood that was mostly a placeholder, but now I'm not sure anymore.

@carromj, I see you were the one who created the original script on pull request #7. How do you think it compares to this approach?

content.raw: Could you add the new dependencies to the Docker file and to the installation tutorial?
content.html: Could you add the new dependencies to the Docker file and to the installation tutorial?

content.raw: It was my understanding that the robots would have flashlights. Caves are naturally dark, right?
content.html: It was my understanding that the robots would have flashlights. Caves are naturally dark, right?

content.raw:
After talking IRL:

* Entrance == exit
* Staging area outside, in the same level as the cave entrance, bounded by jersey barriers
content.html:
After talking IRL:

  • Entrance == exit
  • Staging area outside, in the same level as the cave entrance, bounded by jersey barriers

content.raw: Are the cave meshes placeholders, or is the lighting just dark?
content.html: Are the cave meshes placeholders, or is the lighting just dark?

content.raw: Just a platform on which all the vehicles start. Then they would have to move from the staging area into the cave.
content.html: Just a platform on which all the vehicles start. Then they would have to move from the staging area into the cave.

content.raw: Is it possible to have just one exit?
content.html: Is it possible to have just one exit?

content.raw: You mean like a walled area with a hole to go down to the caves?
content.html: You mean like a walled area with a hole to go down to the caves?

content.raw: Can you make the staging area located outside the cave?
content.html: Can you make the staging area located outside the cave?

content.raw: I'll look into using [RGL](https://github.com/monora/rgl) so we can check that once we start spawning targets
content.html: I'll look into using RGL so we can check that once we start spawning targets

content.raw: I think this is actually important, and currently there isn't a way to check that.
content.html: I think this is actually important, and currently there isn't a way to check that.

content.raw: This may not be so important, but is it possible to make sure that a specific pair of locations \(i.e., start and goal\) are physically connected?
content.html: This may not be so important, but is it possible to make sure that a specific pair of locations (i.e., start and goal) are physically connected?
